Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Phonetic Convergence in Spoken Communication

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Spoken communication works so well that its efficacy is taken for granted. Two complete strangers who meet for the first time and speak the same language can converse with relative ease from the moment of introduction. How is this feat accomplished? The fact that talkers share a language with similar vocabulary and grammatical rules is only part of the answer. Because of the enormous variability in phonetic forms used by speakers of the same language, how an individual speaks is as important as what he or she says. When talkers converse, they often adopt some of the phonetic attributes of their conversational partners, a process termed "phonetic convergence." On other occasions, talkers diverge from each other or show little change in their phonetic repertoire. Moreover, some talkers are more adept than others at shedding an accent or adopting the accent of a foreign language. The current project aims to further our understanding of these interactive effects by investigating the relationship between individual perceptual and learning abilities and acoustic-phonetic variability across both nonsocial and conversational settings. Delineating how individual speakers adjust to each other is crucial to understanding communication in interactive, multi-talker settings.

This project has the potential for broad impact across many domains that rely on social interaction of talkers, such as learning a second language, remediation of speech pathologies, and human-computer interaction through the medium of speech. The award is for Research in Undergraduate Institutions and incorporates undergraduate student participation at all levels of the work, from design and data collection to reporting and presentation of results. The recordings and transcription data will also be made available online to other qualified researchers interested in studying the phenomena of conversational interaction via the Linguistics Data Consortium.

POR.DRECONTENT:
1) Intellectual Merit. This project investigated phonetic form variation in spoken communication. Some of the most important sources of variability in spoken communication arise from differences among talkers and interactive situations. Numerous studies across several research domains find effects of talker and situational differences in speech perception, production, and memory, as well as the dynamics of conversational interaction. To further an understanding of spoken communication with regard to such effects, the project’s activities examined the relation between individual perceptual and learning abilities and acoustic-phonetic variability across both noninteractive and interactive settings. The project was conducted over the course of 4 years and was designed to address the questions, 1) What is the relationship between perceptual sensitivity to talker differences, learning to identify talkers by voice, and variability in phonetic convergence? 2) Do individual differences in the ability to discriminate and to learn to identify talkers by voice predict phonetic convergence in speech production?, and 3) What is the relationship between phonetic convergence in shadowing tasks and convergence in more natural conversational settings of language use? A more complete understanding of the contribution of interactive settings to acoustic-phonetic form can inform basic theories of speech production and perception as well as applications across multiple arenas that rely on spoken communication.

This project developed a new conversational task, the Map Matching Task, and collected a substantial conversational speech corpus (96 talkers total) that can be used to investigate phonetic convergence during conversational interaction as well as many aspects of conversational interaction. The Map Matching Task is a naturalistic role-neutral task that also permits assessment of communicative efficacy through scoring of landmark placement accuracy. The corpus is balanced with regard to talker sex and pair sex—there are equal numbers of male, female, and mixed sex pairs in the corpus. The Map Matching Task, corpus recordings, and associated transcripts and datasets will be made available to other researchers through the Linguistics Data Consortium, per the data sharing plan. Because conversational interaction plays a central role in most human activity, this corpus is especially useful across disciplines such as Social Psychology, Linguistics, and Communication Studies.

Talkers who participated in the conversational task also provided recordings in a speech shadowing task. This task involves simply repeating utterances of other talkers without social interaction. Analyses of speech produced in the shadowing task and in conversational interactions reveals that phonetic convergence in these settings is only weakly related, and that the sex of a talker and a pair influences this relationship. This project is the first of its kind to investigate phonetic convergence in multiple settings in the same set of talkers.

2) Broader Impacts. This project has advanced discovery and understanding while integrating research and education by incorporating undergraduate student participation at all levels of involvement. Data collection was performed on undergraduate students who were paid or participated in the research as part of their introductory psychology curriculum. A total of 21 research assistants were recruited to work part-time during the academic year and summer, and they were given appropriate training to aid in the conduct of the experiments and data analyses. Of these, 2 were graduate students who completed some of the work as part of their Master’s Thesis projects. This project also broadened participation of underrepresented groups in psychological studies by including equal numbers of male and female participants in the speech corpora, and by including members of minority groups in all activities.

Findings from this research have been disseminated to the public in 5 research reports appearing in peer-reviewed scientific journals in the areas of cognitive psychology and psycholinguistics. In addition, the PI traveled to 12 scientific conferences to present her work, and has published 3 research reports in conference proceedings. Moreover, a book chapter describing phonetic convergence in conversational interaction will appear in the forthcoming Handbook of Psycholinguistics.

This project has continued an ongoing program of research by the principle investigator that can contribute to society by increasing an understanding of the cognitive and social mechanisms behind variation in linguistic form and how listeners perceive such variation. By elucidating the role of these factors in spoken communication, this project has the potential for broad impact across many domains that rely on social interaction. For example, it would be useful for linguists conducting field research to be aware of phonetic convergence in order to avoid influencing the forms produced by the subjects of study, and phonetic convergence might ultimately be useful as a diagnostic of the social dynamics between interacting individuals. Moreover, the results of this research have the potential to benefit second language learners who attempt to mimic novel speech forms, and to apply to the remediation of speech pathologies.
